text: Hi. Welcome to 'This is My Architecture'.
I'm Jennifer and I'm here with Nick
from DISH Network.
Hi, Nick. Thanks for joining us today.
Hi, Jennifer. It's a pleasure to be here.

Can you tell us
a little bit about DISH Network?
Absolutely.

DISH Network corporation
is a connectivity company
and a member of the Fortune 250.

DISH is currently building
a cloud-based 5G open radio access network

that'll help run
the smart cities of the future.
Excellent.
Can you walk us through your architecture

and how it's solving
your business challenges today?
Absolutely.

We needed an architecture
that would help us run
hundreds of accounts at scale.

It all starts
with our IT Service Management Tool.
Here, users can use a workflow

to generate
fully automated self-service AWS accounts.

Once the workflow approval conditions
are met,

the ITSM tool will kick off
our account factory
in Control Tower in our root account.

Here a new AWS account is provisioned
from scratch

with all of our necessary account baselines
in place.

Once it's done, the account is ready
for any infrastructure
that needs to be deployed into that account.

Typically, the first thing
that needs to be done is networking.

So a VPC is provisioned
into the vended account
from our service catalog.
During the creation process,

information about what environment
and what resources
that the infrastructure that lives in a VPC

should connect to is collected and applied
in the form of tags to the VPC.
When the VPC comes online,
our Serverless Transit Network Orchestrator
or STNO reads these tags,

and automatically creates
a Transit Gateway attachment

from that VPC to the Transit Gateway
in our core network services account

providing network connectivity from
that vended account
to the other resources in the estate.
Great.

So it seems to me that Transit Gateway
is connecting your VPC

to your Central Network Services account,
correct?
That's correct.

And how many of these accounts
do you have connected
to the Central Services Account?
With the efficiencies and benefits

we were able to get with this
and the self-service capabilities,

we were able to roll out
several hundred of these vended accounts
in a space of only 6 months.

And eventually,
when your VPCs are being deployed,

how are you leveraging these
for your internal stakeholders?

Once the VPC is deployed,
our internal stakeholders are free to deploy

whatever infrastructure they need to support
the workloads they're running.

Frequently, they'll turn to
the Service Catalog

to continue to deploy other resources
like EC2-based web apps,
EKS-based web apps, and RDS databases.

Thank you, Nick,
for walking us through this architecture.

It's been interesting to learn
how DISH Network is creating

a self-service portal
to create multiple accounts at scale.

And thank you for watching
'This is My Architecture'.
